The essential part of Geissler’s Exhaustor 
is a large glass-ball, containing 10-20
Kilos of mercury, which in its upper part 
com[m]unicates by means of a twofold per 
forated stopcock of glass either with the 
free air or with the spectral tube to be 
evacuated. From the lower part of the 
ball, which is invariably fixed, descends 
a longer tube of glass communicating 
at its lower extremity with a moveable 
similar tube, the free end of which enters 
into a large open bottle. When this bottle 
with the moveable tube is lifted up, the 
mercury within the apparatus entirely 
fills the ball, if com[m]unicating with the air.
